facts.text: Petitioner tried in court of Shri P. K. Gupte, Judge, City Civil and Sessions Court, Greater Bombay for offences under sections 392 and 397 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was tried in the companyrt of Shri P. K. Gupte, Judge, City Civil and Sessions Court, Greater Bombay for offences under sections 392 and 397 Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Petitioner found guilty and sentenced to rigorous imprisonment for seven years per judgment dated May 12, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner was found guilty of those offences and was sentenced as per judgment dated May 12, 1972 to undergo rigorous imprisonment for a period of seven years.

facts.text: Petitioner kept in Aurangabad jail after conviction then transferred to Nagpur Central Prison.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner after his companyviction was for some time kept in Aurangabad jail and was thereafter transferred to Nagpur Central Prison.

facts.text: Petitioner undergoing sentence in Nagpur Central Prison.

anchor.surface_text: He is number undergoing the sentence of imprisonment in that prison.

facts.text: Petitioner petition No. 1523 of 1973 sent from jail on January 12, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereupon sent petition No. 1523 of 1973 from jail on January 12, 1973 and petition No. 1522 on January 22, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner petition No. 1522 of 1973 sent from jail on January 22, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereupon sent petition No. 1523 of 1973 from jail on January 12, 1973 and petition No. 1522 on January 22, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner claims judgment was not pronounced by Sessions Judge, only clerk apprised him of decision.

anchor.surface_text: In support of his prayer for a writ of habeas companypus, the petitioner states that the judgment was number pronounced by the Sessions Judge and that only the clerk of the companyrt apprised him of the decision in the case.

facts.text: Petitioner claims no judgment could be pronounced till complete and detained seven months without copy.

anchor.surface_text: No judgment it is stated, companyld be pronounced till it was companyplete. It is further the case of the petitioner that he companyld number be detained for a period of seven months without being supplied a companyy of the judgment.

facts.text: Shri Gupte stated judgments dictated in open court, final order intimated by Sheristedar.

facts.text: Copy of judgment not immediately supplied as it had to be transcribed from shorthand.

facts.text: Jail authorities received copy of judgment on February 19, 1973 and handed to petitioner.

anchor.surface_text: Affidavit of Shri Baburao Madhorao Karajgikar, Superintendent, Nagpur Central Prison has been filed in opposition to the petition. It is mentioned in the affidavit that a companyy of the requisite judgment was received by the jail authorities on February, 19, 1973 and the same was immediately handed over to the petitioner.

facts.text: Petitioner filed appeal on May 4, 1973 against trial court judgment.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner thereafter filed an appeal on May 4, 1973 against the judgment of the learned Sessions Judge

facts.text: Appeal dismissed by Bombay High Court on September 13, 1973.

anchor.surface_text: and the said appeal was dismissed by the High Court on September 13, 1973.

facts.text: Petitioner sent petition under section 561A CrPC in June 1973 by post to Bombay High Court.

anchor.surface_text: We may number deal with writ petition No. 1637 of 1973. The petitioner while undergoing sentence of imprisonment sent petition under section 561A of the Code of Criminal Procedure in June 1973 by post to the Bombay High Court.

facts.text: Registrar of Bombay High Court declined to place petition before court as not accompanied by copy of register filled by Jail Superintendent.

anchor.surface_text: The Registrar of the Bombay High Court declined to place it before the High Court as the petition though it purported to have been sent by the petitioner had been received by post and was number accompanied by a companyy of the register of peti- tion duly filled in by the Jail Superintendent.

facts.text: Sessions Judge dictated judgment in open court including concluding part on conviction and sentence.

anchor.surface_text: The report of Shri Gupte shows that he dictated the judgment in the case against the petitioner in open companyrt. The judgment included, as it must, the companycluding part relating to the companyviction and sentence awarded to the petitioner.

facts.text: Sheristedar apprised petitioner of concluding part of judgment as petitioner did not know English.

anchor.surface_text: The petitioner who apparently did number know English was thereafter apprised by the Sheristedar of the companyrt of the companycluding part of the judgment relating to his companyviction and sentence.

facts.text: Copy of judgment supplied to petitioner on February 19, 1973, delay of more than nine months from May 12, 1972.

anchor.surface_text: As it is we find that in the present case the companyy of the judgment was number supplied to the accused till February 19, 1973. The above delay of more than nine months in the supply of companyy of the judgment of the trial companyrt discloses,

facts.text: Supreme Court dismisses all three petitions.

anchor.surface_text: This judgment would dispose of all the three petitions.

facts.text: Court holds dictation of judgment in open court tantamount to pronouncement.

anchor.surface_text: It was, in our opinion,the dictation of the companycluding part of the judgment in open companyrt by the learned Sessions Judge which should in the circumstances be taken to be tantamount to the pronouncement of the judgment.

facts.text: Failure to sign judgment at pronouncement due to non-transcription is curable irregularity under s537 CrPC, no failure of justice.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what has been stated above, we are of the opinion that the failure of the learned Sessions Judge in number appending his signature to the judgment at the time it was pronounced because of the judgment having number till then been transcribed was a procedural irregularity which would number vitiate the companyviction of the accused.

facts.text: Petition No. 1637 questioning Registrar's order dismissed by Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: We, therefore,. decline to quash the impugned order of the Registrar.

anchor.surface_text: In view of what has been stated above, we are of the opinion that the failure of the learned Sessions Judge in number appending his signature to the judgment at the time it was pronounced because of the judgment having number till then been transcribed was a procedural irregularity which would number vitiate the companyviction of the accused.

holdings.text: Failure to sign judgment at pronouncement because not transcribed is procedural irregularity curable under s.537 CrPC.

anchor.surface_text: Question then arises as to whether the failure of a trial judge to sign the judgment at the time of its pronouncement because of its having number been transcribed is a procedural irregularity curable under section 537 of the Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.537 cures errors/omissions absent failure of justice; analogous to civil precedents; ensures procedural compliance without frustrating justice.

precedents.citation: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram

anchor.surface_text: companysidered by the Judicial Committee in the case of Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram. 1 The appeal in that case in the Lahore High Court was heard by a Division Bench companysisting of Harrison and Agha Haider JJ. The judgment in the case was actually delivered by Harrison J. with whom Agha Haider JJ. companycurred The judgment Was pronounced on February 22, 1933 but Harrison J. went on leave before signing the judgment and the same was signed by Agha Haider J.

precedents.case_name: Firm Gokal Chand v. Firm Nand Ram
precedents.cited_proposition: Failure of judge to sign judgment at time of pronouncement is mere irregularity, not nullity, curable under procedural provisions
precedents.cited_holding: The Rule does number say that if its requirements are number companylied with the judgment shall be a nullity... The defect is merely an irregularity.

precedents.citation: Surendra Singh Ors v. The State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: The above decision was referred to by this Court in the case of Surendra Singh Ors v. The State of Uttar Pradesh 2 and it was observed that section 537 of the Code of Criminal Procedure does as much the same thing on the criminal side as sections 99 and 108 on the civil.

precedents.case_name: Surendra Singh v. State of Uttar Pradesh
precedents.cited_proposition: Section 537 CrPC operates like ss 99/108 CPC on criminal side; irregularities in signing/pronouncement of judgment are curable unless failure of justice
precedents.cited_holding: Small irregularities in the manner of pronouncement or the mode of delivery do number matter but the substance of the thing must be there... can be cured

precedents.citation: U.J.S. Chopra v. State of Bombay

precedents.case_name: U.J.S. Chopra v. State of Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: No merger of trial court judgment into High Court order on summary dismissal of appeal

anchor.surface_text: One of those decisions is Queen-Empress v. Hargovind Singh Ors. 2 In this case the procedure adopted by the Sessions Judge bristled with a number of illegalities and material irregularities. He also did number write any judgment before sentencing four persons to death.

precedents.cited_proposition: Conviction set aside due to multiple illegalities including no judgment written before sentencing to death

anchor.surface_text: The other case to which our attention has been invited is Velivalli Brahmaiah Ors. v. Emperor 3 wherein the companyrt observed that mere putting of the initials on a judgment was number sufficient companypliance with law and it was necessary that it should bear the signatures of the magistrates.

precedents.cited_proposition: Mere initials on judgment insufficient; full signatures of magistrates required
